Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, helping my stepmom set out plates for our first big family holiday dinner together. She smiled at me, clearly happy I was finally joining in, and my dad gave me a thumbs-up from across the room. I knew how much it meant to them that I was here, trying to be part of this new family. Just as I started folding napkins, my phone buzzed. It was Sam, my best friend, panicked and nearly in tears. She was already on her way to the airport for her grandmother’s funeral and thought she’d left her passport at home. “Can you check my room and bring it if it’s there? Please, I’ll miss my flight otherwise.” My heart pounded. I could see the hope in my stepmom’s eyes, the way she wanted me to belong. But Sam needed me—she’d do the same for me in a heartbeat. I stared at my phone, torn between the family I was trying to build and the friend who’d always been there.
